name: turla

procedures: T1005::[Turla] RPC backdoors can upload files from victim machines.
T1007::[Turla] surveys a system upon check-in to discover running services and associated processes using the tasklist /svc command.
T1012::[Turla] surveys a system upon check-in to discover information in the Windows Registry with the reg query command.
T1016.001::[Turla] has used tracert to check internet connectivity.
T1016::[Turla] surveys a system upon check-in to discover network configuration details using the arp -a, nbtstat -n, net config, ipconfig /all, and route commands, as well as [NBTscan].

T1018::[Turla] surveys a system upon check-in to discover remote systems on a local network using the net view and net view /DOMAIN commands. [Turla] has also used net group "Domain Computers" /domain, net group "Domain Controllers" /domain, and net group "Exchange Servers" /domain to enumerate domain computers, including the organization's DC and Exchange Server.
T1021.002::[Turla] used net use commands to connect to lateral systems within a network.
T1025::[Turla] RPC backdoors can collect files from USB thumb drives.
T1027.005::Based on comparison of [Gazer] versions, [Turla] made an effort to obfuscate strings in the malware that could be used as IoCs, including the mutex name and named pipe.
T1027::[Turla] has used encryption (including salted 3DES via [PowerSploit]'s Out-EncryptedScript.ps1), random variable names, and base64 encoding to obfuscate PowerShell commands and payloads.
T1049::[Turla] surveys a system upon check-in to discover active local network connections using the netstat -an, net use, net file, and net session commands.
T1055.001::[Turla] has used Metasploit to perform reflective DLL injection in order to escalate privileges.
T1055::[Turla] has also used [PowerSploit]'s Invoke-ReflectivePEInjection.ps1 to reflectively load a PowerShell payload into a random process on the victim system.
T1057::[Turla] surveys a system upon check-in to discover running processes using the tasklist /v command.

T1059.001::[Turla] has used PowerShell to execute commands/scripts, in some cases via a custom executable or code from [Empire]'s PSInject. has also used PowerShell scripts to load and execute malware in memory.
T1059.003::[Turla] RPC backdoors have used cmd.exe to execute commands.
T1059.005::[Turla] has used VBS scripts throughout its operations.
T1059.006::[Turla] has used IronPython scripts as part of the [IronNetInjector] toolchain to drop payloads.
T1059.007::[Turla] has used various JavaScript-based backdoors.
T1068::[Turla] has exploited vulnerabilities in the VBoxDrv.sys driver to obtain kernel mode privileges.
T1069.001::[Turla] has used net localgroup and net localgroup Administrators to enumerate group information, including members of the local administrators group.
T1069.002::[Turla] has used net group "Domain Admins" /domain to identify domain administrators.
T1071.001::[Turla] has used HTTP and HTTPS for C2 communications.
T1071.003::[Turla] has used multiple backdoors which communicate with a C2 server via email attachments.
T1078.003::[Turla] has abused local accounts that have the same password across the victim’s network.
T1082::[Turla] surveys a system upon check-in to discover operating system configuration details using the systeminfo and set commands.
T1083::[Turla] surveys a system upon check-in to discover files in specific locations on the hard disk %TEMP% directory, the current user's desktop, the Program Files directory, and Recent.
T1087.001::[Turla] has used net user to enumerate local accounts on the system.
T1087.002::[Turla] has used net user /domain to enumerate domain accounts.
T1090.001::[Turla] has compromised internal network systems to act as a proxy to forward traffic to C2.
T1090::[Turla] RPC backdoors have included local UPnP RPC proxies.
T1102.002::A [Turla] JavaScript backdoor has used Google Apps Script as its C2 server.
T1102::[Turla] has used legitimate web services including Pastebin, Dropbox, and GitHub for C2 communications.
T1105::[Turla] has used shellcode to download Meterpreter after compromising a victim.
T1106::[Turla] and its RPC backdoors have used APIs calls for various tasks related to subverting AMSI and accessing then executing commands through RPC and/or named pipes.
T1110::[Turla] may attempt to connect to systems within a victim's network using net use commands and a predefined list or collection of passwords.
T1112::[Turla] has used the Registry to store encrypted payloads.
T1120::[Turla] has used fsutil fsinfo drives to list connected drives.
T1124::[Turla] surveys a system upon check-in to discover the system time by using the net time command.
T1134.002::[Turla] RPC backdoors can impersonate or steal process tokens before executing commands.
T1140::[Turla] has used a custom decryption routine, which pulls key and salt values from other artifacts such as a WMI filter or [PowerShell Profile], to decode encrypted PowerShell payloads.
T1189::[Turla] has infected victims using watering holes.
T1201::[Turla] has used net accounts and net accounts /domain to acquire password policy information.
T1204.001::[Turla] has used spearphishing via a link to get users to download and run their malware.
T1213::[Turla] has used a custom .NET tool to collect documents from an organization's internal central database.
T1518.001::[Turla] has obtained information on security software, including security logging information that may indicate whether their malware has been detected.
T1546.003::[Turla] has used WMI event filters and consumers to establish persistence.
T1546.013::[Turla] has used PowerShell profiles to maintain persistence on an infected machine.

T1547.001::A [Turla] Javascript backdoor added a local_update_check value under the Registry key HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run to establish persistence. Additionally, a [Turla] custom executable containing Metasploit shellcode is saved to the Startup folder to gain persistence.
T1547.004::[Turla] established persistence by adding a Shell value under the Registry key HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon.
T1553.006::[Turla] has modified variables in kernel memory to turn off Driver Signature Enforcement after exploiting vulnerabilities that obtained kernel mode privileges.
T1555.004::[Turla] has gathered credentials from the Windows Credential Manager tool.
T1560.001::[Turla] has encrypted files stolen from connected USB drives into a RAR file before exfiltration.
T1562.001::[Turla] has used a AMSI bypass, which patches the in-memory amsi.dll, in PowerShell scripts to bypass Windows antimalware products.
T1566.002::[Turla] attempted to trick targets into clicking on a link featuring a seemingly legitimate domain from Adobe.com to download their malware and gain initial access.
T1567.002::[Turla] has used WebDAV to upload stolen USB files to a cloud drive.
T1570::[Turla] RPC backdoors can be used to transfer files to/from victim machines on the local network.
T1583.006::[Turla] has created web accounts including Dropbox and GitHub for C2 and document exfiltration.
T1584.003::[Turla] has used the VPS infrastructure of compromised Iranian threat actors.
T1584.004::[Turla] has used compromised servers as infrastructure.
T1584.006::[Turla] has frequently used compromised WordPress sites for C2 infrastructure.
T1587.001::[Turla] has developed its own unique malware for use in operations.
T1588.001::[Turla] has used malware obtained after compromising other threat actors, such as [OilRig].
T1588.002::[Turla] has obtained and customized publicly-available tools like [Mimikatz].
T1615::[Turla] surveys a system upon check-in to discover Group Policy details using the gpresult command.

description: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) is a Russian-based threat group that has infected victims in over 45 countries, spanning a range of industries including government, embassies, military, education, research and pharmaceutical companies since 2004. Heightened activity was seen in mid-2015. [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) is known for conducting watering hole and spearphishing campaigns and leveraging in-house tools and malware. [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010)’s espionage platform is mainly used against Windows machines, but has also been seen used against macOS and Linux machines.(Citation: Kaspersky Turla)(Citation: ESET Gazer Aug 2017)(Citation: CrowdStrike VENOMOUS BEAR)(Citation: ESET Turla Mosquito Jan 2018)
